questions.text: A child had a history of stab injury on the anterior abdominal wall and the image is shown below. The child is hemodynamically stable. Which will be the next course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Emergency laparotomy

The next course of treatment in the given scenario of a stab injury to the abdomen with the image showing evisceration of the omentum is emergency laparotomy.

Emergency laparotomy is performed to explore and repair abdominal injuries in case of

- Hemodynamic instability

- Peritonitis

- Evisceration

- Diffuse abdominal pain

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below that is used to create a pneumoperitoneum ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Veress needle

The given Image showing a long, slender laparoscopic instrument is Veress Needle. It is used in direct puncture laparoscopy to produce a pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: A surgeon is performing an open cholecystectomy and uses the following instrument to lift the liver up. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Deaver’s retractor

The given image is of the Deaver’s Retractor. It is specifically designed for holding the liver up out of the way during a cholecystectomy. It needs to be used carefully to avoid damaging the liver.

questions.text: A patient was received in the casualty following a road traffic accident. His BP was 90/60 mmHg and his pulse rate was 120/min. The emergency room physician asked you to replace the fluid loss in this patient. What is the maximum flow rate of fluid with the IV canula given in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

90 ml/min

The green IV cannula used in this hemodynamically unstable patient is an 18G cannula, which has a maximum flow rate of 90 ml/min.

choices.text: To hold tough tissue like skin and fascia

questions.text: For what purpose would you use the instrument shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

To carry out blunt dissection

The above Image is of Lister’s sinus forceps which are used for blunt dissection.

It is used during Hilton’s method of abscess drainage to break the bacterial loculi.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

The given condition is likely to be Fournier gangrene. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

Fournier’s gangrene is a polymicrobial infection and a type of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region. Risk factors include immunocompromised states such as HIV, alcoholism, and diabetes. The infection may be precipitated by minor procedures in the perineal area, such as a bruise, scratch, urethral dilatation, injection of hemorrhoids, or opening of a periurethral abscess. The infection spreads along the dartos, Scarpa, and Colles fascia.

questions.text: A peripherally Inserted central catheter line(PICC) was placed in a patient to provide parenteral nutrition. Following the insertion, a chest X-ray was taken, which appeared as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the ideal position of the tip of this catheter?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Superior vena cava The ideal position of the tip of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line, is superior vena cava. Peripherally inserted central catheters are commonly used for providing parenteral nutrition therapy. They are inserted through veins in the upper arm, and guided into the central venous system, such that the tip of the catheter enters the superior vena cava. A chest X-ray is taken to confirm the position of the tip. PICC lines have the advantage of minimizing inconvenience to the patients and clinicians. However, if the patient develops thrombophlebitis, the PICC line may be destroyed.

questions.text:
A man presented to the emergency department after RTA with complaints of chest pain and breathing difficulty. An X-ray was done and is given below. What type of breathing pattern is observed in this patient?

RTA-Road Traffic Accident
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Contiguous rib fractures, especially when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in two or more places, result in a condition known as a flail chest. This creates a free-floating segment of the chest wall, which moves independently from the rest of the thoracic cage.

In such cases:

•   During inspiration, the negative intrathoracic pressure pulls the flail segment inward, opposite to the rest of the chest wall.

•   During expiration, the segment bulges outward, again opposite to the normal movement.

This paradoxical movement leads to:

•   Inefficient ventilation

•   Increased work of breathing

•   Hypoxia

•   Pain that further limits chest expansion

X-ray Findings Consistent With Flail Chest:

•   Multiple adjacent rib fractures

•   Possibly associated pulmonary contusion (often seen in trauma)

•   Irregular or displaced rib margins

Clinical Correlation:

•   In trauma cases like this:

•   Paradoxical chest movement is a clinical hallmark of flail chest

•   Management may include analgesia, oxygen therapy, and sometimes mechanical ventilation depending on respiratory compromise

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jackson-Pratt drain

The given image is of a Jackson-Pratt drain.

Drains are placed at surgical sites to freely drain the air or fluids that may accumulate. They promote wound healing by preventing the formation of unnecessary cavities. Drains can be:

- Open: They are based on the principle of gravity

- Semi-open: Their action is based on capillary effect

- Closed: They carry out their actions through suction

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures

From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument.

questions.text: The type of knot seen In the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reef knot

The given image shows the suture material exiting the knot is on the same side as the entry i.e no cross-over is seen.

A knot is a fastening made of threads intertwined together or on themselves. Each knot consists of- 2 half-hitches placed in sequential throws. Squaring refers to tightening the knot/half-hitch in a manner that the threads lay flat due to the alternating direction of half-hitches in adjacent layers.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Doyen’s mouth gag

Doyen’s mouth gag is used to keep the mouth open for intraoral surgery when retraction of the tongue is not required or desirable. Mostly used for tongue surgery. It is applied on one side of the mouth on the molar teeth.

questions.text: Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Trophic ulcer

The given picture showing an ulcer with punched-out edges over a pressure point is most likely that of a trophic ulcer/neuropathic ulcer.

A neuropathic ulcer is one that occurs as a result of peripheral neuropathy. In peripheral neuropathy, lack of sensation over the pressure points leads to cumulative microtrauma, minor wounds, or cuts that remain unnoticed but eventually develop into ulcers.

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the below image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

20 G

The given cannula is 20 gauge IV cannula as its color code is pink.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with an indirect inguinal hernia. The surgeon uses the suture material given in the image below for the hernia repair. It is a polyamide polymer that undergoes degradation and loses tensile strength at the rate of 15-20% every year. Identify the suture material.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nylon

The suture material is nylon.

Nylon is a monofilament or braided multifilament type non absorbable suture material. It is a polyamide polymer with low tissue reaction and is used in skin closure, abdominal wall mass closure, hernia repair, plastic surgery, neurosurgery, microsurgery, ophthalmic surgery, etc. However, it also loses 15-20% of its tensile strength every year and degrades at the rate of 15-20% every year.

choices.text: Both hepatic arterial and Portal venous bleeding

questions.text:
A young man with a history of blunt abdominal trauma was brought to the emergency department. He was hemodynamically unstable, and a FAST examination revealed free fluid. An immediate laparotomy was done. The maneuver shown in the image below was performed due to severe bleeding near the liver. However, the bleeding continued. What could be the probable source of the bleeding in this case?

FAST-Focussed assessment with sonography in trauma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hepatic vein bleeding

The image shows clamping of the hepatoduodenal ligament, which is done in the Pringle maneuver. Bleeding that is not controlled by this maneuver suggests that the source of the bleeding is the hepatic vein.

The Pringle manoeuvre is performed in surgery when there is excessive bleeding from the liver to temporarily arrest the bleeding and identify the source of the bleed, and is especially helpful in traumatic liver injury. With the occlusion of the portal triad, the inflow from the hepatic artery and portal vein are controlled, but backflow from the IVC and hepatic vein persists. After performing this maneuver, the liver laceration can be explored, and further bleeding can be controlled.

questions.text: You observe a patient being operated upon in the given position in the operation theatre. What could be the likely surgery being performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy

The above image shows the reverse Trendelenburg position, where the patient’s head is elevated 15-30 degrees higher than the feet. It is named so, as the position is reverse of the Trendelenburg position, where the head end is lower and the feet are at a higher level.

The Trendelenburg and reverse Trendelenburg positions are used in surgeries that are required to move the abdominal viscera, such as the small bowel, away from the operative field. Restraints and sideboards are placed to prevent the patient from sliding from the bed.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents to the emergency room with bloody vomitus. Vital signs show a BP of 90/70 mm Hg, pulse 110 bpm, and SpO2-97%. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and a distended abdomen with spider nevi. The bleeding is immediately controlled using the instrument shown in the image. Identify the instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sengstaken Blakemore tube

The above image shows the Sengstaken Blakemore tube.

The given clinical scenario- a chronic alcoholic with hematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding, in which temporary hemostasis can be achieved with the help of balloon tamponades.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. 1 suction tube and 2 inflation tubes. The 3 openings are the gastric balloon port, esophageal balloon port, and the gastric aspiration port

Only gastric contents can be aspirated.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube should be decompressed every 12 hours to prevent necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below?.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Negative pressure wound therapy

The given image shows negative pressure wound therapy using a vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) device to promote healing in chronic wounds.
Principle: An intermittent negative pressure of -125 mmHg hastens debridement and formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds.

Indications: Chronic wounds (such as diabetic foot ulcers, stage III and IV pressure ulcers), traumatic wounds, flaps and grafts, and dehisced incisions.

questions.text: The operating surgeon performed the following suture technique on the skin after appendicectomy surgery. This is called
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Mattress suture

This suture technique is called mattress suture.

The type of mattress suture performed is horizontal mattress suture. It is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edge of the wound and moving horizontally and traverse once again both the edge of the wound and tie the knot.
